title: Friday, 15th April, 2016

Deutsche have this detailed note on helicopter money

PM

PM

But it's something of a must read

11:09 am
PM

Here's the blurb

PM

n As the developed world "turns Japanese" and Abenomics turns full circle, investors are questioning the limits of monetary policy. In this report we assess the likelihood and impact of the ultimate monetary policy tool: central bank monetary financing.

n Little has been written on the practical implementation of "helicopter money". We focus on the historical experience, the legal constraints and potential market impact in the US, Europe, Japan and the UK.

n We categorize money financing into four different policy options– central bank purchases of government bonds with fiscal expansion (similar to QE), cash transfers to the government, write-downs of central bank holdings of government debt, and direct money transfers to the public.

PM

We investigate the historical backdrop and institutional constraints behind the different policy options. The constraints are lower than is commonly assumed, even for the ECB. The Fed and Bank of England have the greatest precedent and flexibility in monetary financing.

n We argue that "helicopter money" could be far more impactful than QE or fiscal policy, subject to the conversion of private and public liabilities into a perpetuity and central bank tolerance for infinite losses.

n The potential market impact of "helicopter money" can be substantial, although highly dependent on inflation expectations. A "successful" policy should lead to higher yields, higher equities, and a weaker currency.

n We conclude that monetary financing may be more likely than commonly assumed. With Japan fast approaching the limits of its existing reflation project, it is a canary in the coalmine for the next global policy innovat

(Yes, we're contractually obliged to run that screenshot every time Poundland's mentioned.)

11:18 am
BE

HSBC goes down to hold.

BE

4Q core trading showed deterioration with no recovery expected until 2H17; as a result we cut our forecasts
99p Stores progressing well with confidence on "GBP25m incremental EBITDA" but has required heavy investment
Downgrade to Hold, TP cut to 160p (from 290p); lower forecasts, lack of momentum and higher risk drive rating cut

BE

Andrew Porteous is the analyst.

11:19 am
BE

4Q16 sales of GBP331m compared to our forecast of GBP348m with the difference driven by lower sales from 99p Stores and ongoing weakness in core trading. The difference in 99p Stores sales is of little concern given the sensitivity to the timing of conversions. Importantly, management remains confident that the company will generate "at least GBP25m incremental EBITDA" from 99p Stores. However, weak core trading is a concern. In our view, the distraction of integrating 99p Stores is a legitimate reason for lost focus on the core. However, the extent and duration of this is a surprise and momentum appears to have deteriorated, with no improvement in 4Q despite materially easier comparatives and little prospect of near-term relief.

Recovery postponed. We had previously expected core trading to improve as comparatives eased and 99p Stores conversions were completed. However, given the extent of the disruption, management expect s1H17 LFL growth to remain negative with improvement in 2H. At the same time, the need to focus on extracting the benefits of the business' increased scale mean that planned store openings have been reduced. The business now plans to open only 30-40 stores in the UK and Ireland in FY17 vs a historical run rate of 60. After the integration openings should return to closer to the historical rate. Nevertheless, growth expectations need to be downgraded.

Slower growth is disappointing and drives earnings downgrades. We cut sales by c5-6% reflecting weaker LFL growth and lower openings in FY17e. We cut our underlying PBT forecasts by 8-15% for FY16-18e, given operational gearing impacts. We are also concerned that the required investment to stabilise 99p Stores has been a major drag on cash flow, sending the business to a net debt position. While some of this is working capital driven and should reverse, the business has historically strived to maintain a net cash position. Moving into net debt, given the lack of core momentum and operational gearing, is a step up in the risk profile.

Rating down to Hold (from Buy), TP cut to 160p (from 290p). Our previous Buy rating was predicated on a stabilisation of the core with incremental benefits to come from 99p Stores. While 99p Stores is on track, core recovery has been postponed and momentum has deteriorated at a time when management change presents a further risk. We cut our DCF-derived target to 160p (from 290p) on lower forecasts, terminal growth (0% from 1%) and terminal margin (3% from 3.7%) and with a higher WACC driven by updated cost of equity and beta (1.5 from 1.2) assumptions.

BE

Cool. Here's Goldman.

BE

Given the challenging market backdrop, we expect the stable AUM and
positive flow trends reported by Man Group in 1Q16 to reassure investors.
In addition, today’s statement highlights two positive trends that we
expect will help drive a positive market reaction.

11:28 am
BE

Implications
Man Group’s first-quarter FUM ($79 bn) and flows ($400 mn) were in line
with our expectations. We suspect the strength of this performance will
become more evident as other asset managers report their FUM & flows
for the difficult 1Q16 period. Looking beneath these headline figures, we
find two aspects of the results particularly encouraging:
1. Strong AHL sales – The $1.3 bn net flow into Man’s suite of AHL
products was far in excess of our $0.3 bn forecast. With gross redemptions
sequentially flat in 1Q16, this strength reflects an acceleration in investor
demand. Indeed, gross AHL sales of $1.9 bn were the strongest since Man
Group adopted its current disclosure three years ago.
2. Strong US sales– $0.4 bn of AHL sales this quarter were via US openended vehicles, suggesting that management’s efforts to expand the
group’s US distribution capacity continue to gain traction. We estimate
more than one-quarter of the group’s FUM is now managed for US clients

BE

Valuation
Our 2016-20 EPS rises by low single digits (1.4%-3.0%) as we incorporate
today’s results. Our 12-month price target remains unchanged at 200p,
based upon a methodology that applies a target P/E of 16x to 2017E
management fee EPS and 2/3 this multiple to performance fee EPS.

BE

And Barclays.

11:30 am
BE

Man Group’s Q1 16 net inflows of $0.5bn was more resilient than the -£1.3bn outflows we were expecting. Partially offsetting this was negative market mvmt/other of -$0.6bn, weaker than the +$0.3bn we projected. As a result AUM at end Mar-16 was $78.6bn virtually flat on Dec-15’s $78.7bn and 1% beat vs the $77.7bn we were going for. Unsurprisingly, given volatile markets in Q1, flows have slowed down sequentially vs $1.4bn and $1.5bn in prior qtrs. $1.7bn net inflows into AHL was mainly counteracted by -$1.1bn out of GLG. AHL and GLG performance also had diverging fortunes with $0.8bn +ve invt mvmt for AHL more than offset by -$1.5bn out of GLG. Management outlook was cautious saying ongoing uncertainty is making markets challenging and clients’ low risk appetite has the potential to impact flows. As previously signaled management continues to look for acquisitions, which are likely to be midsized bolt-ons in our opinion, similar to the completed transactions made in 2015. The share is down -14% ytd vs FTSE Allshare -1% and trading at 11x 2016 PE

11:33 am

Well, seems the rumour has got a retread

BE

Stifel makes the valuation argument today.

BE

Recent trading: Like-for-like sales were 1.5% ahead in 2015, but there was a
1% decline in the last seven weeks of the year. This weaker trend continued
into 2016 and LFLS were down 1.5% in the first 10 weeks, although the
opening weeks of the year were stronger. Accordingly the underlying recent
trend is perhaps -2%, at best. This is attributed to weaker economic conditions
and increased competition in the sector. The business has a high level of
operational gearing and we estimate each 1% change in sales equates to
£3-4m of profit. Against this we consider there are opportunities to reduce
central costs and note that above unit overheads were £38.0m in 2015, up
£3.6m on the previous year.
New openings: We expect some modest scaling back of the new opening
programme for 2016. While the group continues to achieve high returns on
capital from its expansion programme, with payback periods of under three
years, in the light of the trading background it is natural to take a slightly more
prudent attitude. Accordingly there could be around 38 new openings this year,
compared to 44 in 2015.
As with any multi-site operator, the group has some underperforming units but
there are only a handful of loss-making sites, as evidenced by the modest
onerous lease provision of £3.7m. These sites mainly relate to historical leases
signed in the 1990s by previous management, and some legacy sites that
have been sub-let.
Finance: The group is in a healthy financial position, with net debt of £28.4m
at December 2015, compared to the group’s £140m bank facility. The financial
position remains very healthy, in our view, with net debt/EBITDA of 0.2x,
although there are significant leasehold rental payments of £74m per annum.
Our forecasts indicate an underlying free cash flow of £85m, before spending
on new units, and accordingly the free cash flow yield is a highly attractive
11.6%.
Forecasts: We revise our like-for-like sales assumption from flat to -1% for
2016 and downgrade our pre-tax profit forecast by £5m to £85m, which
assumes a 100 basis point reduction in operating margins to 12.0%.
Valuation: On our revised forecasts the rating of the shares looks low at under
11x earnings and around 6x EBITDA. There is a dividend yield of 4.8% and
the underlying free cash flow yield is over 11%. Certainly private equity
companies have paid much higher multiples in recent times. In addition to its
main leisure restaurant brands we note that the group owns a successful
concessions business, an attractive pub restaurant chain of 54 units, and
material freehold property assets. On page 4 we arrive at a sum-of-the-parts
valuation of 492p per share. We consider the shares look undervalued on a
number of criteria, although cautious investors may wish to see evidence that
downgrades to earnings estimates have stabilised.

11:34 am

BE

BE

Frankly, any fund manager whose idea is "sell the housebuilders because Brexit" should probably think about other careers by now.

BE

Sellside's been remorselessly positive on the builders too, in spite of Brexit.

11:39 am
BE

Barclays did an epic a few days ago, which I'll quote at length.

PM

Go on then

BE

UK Referendum risk continues to weigh heavily

Although judged on the latest bookmaker odds, the likelihood of a UK vote
to leave the EU remains relatively low (the average odds on Oddschecker
on 11 April were a c.30% probability that the UK votes to leave), we know
from recent experience that election outcomes can surprise – the Scottish
Independence vote was closer than previously expected, and the General
Election outcome defied most commentators.

11:40 am
BE

With this in mind, this would seem an opportune time to revisit some
referendum-related concerns:

· Effect on the macro economy - the basic context here is that any
adverse impact on the economy is likely to impact house prices (on at
least two occasions in recent years, falls in GDP have been accompanied
by falls in house prices – a chart showing this appears in our housing
market chart book - figure 4). In this context, our economists’ recent
note ‘Thinking Macro - Consequences Of A UK Exit’ is well worthy of a
read. In this, the team asserts that, in its Hypothetical Exit Scenario
(HES), the UK economy would contract in the second half of this year and
by -0.5% in 2017 (“we estimate that GDP would contract by 0.5% in 2017,
with both domestic and external demand contributing negatively to
activity”). Although the implied decline is relatively modest, it would
represent a meaningful movement from the team’s current (status quo - UK
remains in the EU) baseline of 1.8% growth in 2017.

· Availability of migrant (and skilled) labour – house builders rely on
labour from a number of overseas countries, including Poland. This labour
is currently able to work here and makes a significant contribution to
the UK construction segment, among other areas. As this comes at a time
when the house builders already face labour shortages across most skilled
trades, any future restrictions on freedom of movement will cause
concerns. Given the government’s commitment to boost new housing supply,
it would seem counter-intuitive to allow measures that would adversely
impact the supply chain. Here, we draw on a precedent from overseas. In
Australia, for example, those seeking inward migration under the General
Skilled Migration categories must have a nominated occupation on the
Skilled Occupations List at the time of application – there is scope for
similar measures to be implemented here if required.

BE

· Impact on currency – as we have noted recently, sterling is currently
very weak against the US Dollar (the key currency, in our view, given its
long standing peg against the Hong Kong Dollar). On the face of it, this
makes London property more attractive to dollar-denominated buyers, just
as it did back in 2009/2010 when home prices in the capital started their
recovery (and, generally speaking, house prices elsewhere did not).
Although weak sterling presents inflationary risks, these do not seem
onerous at this stage, based on the ten-year bond yield (currently
c1.4%). As such, the market’s expectation is currently that rates fall
first before rising gently in the medium term. Again drawing on the
research of our Economics Team, the model used in the report above
predicts that “GBP weakness would be most pronounced immediately after a
UK exit (10% depreciation of the GBP NEER in Q3 2016) but would gradually
recover about two thirds of these losses by end 2017”.

· Impact on mortgage rates – in principle, anything that changes
Britain’s status within the global economy could impact the cost of
lending. As the starting point is one of record low mortgage rates
(certainly on 75% LTVs), these risks would seem to be relatively well
contained.

Despite the likelihood of a UK decision to leave remaining relatively
modest, the resulting uncertainty is sufficient to imply that the share
price performance of the house builders will remain subdued until the 23rd
June (or the earlier of this date and the date on which the market were
to potentially accept that the UK is not leaving the EU).

BE

Sector rotation has been towards oil/gas/mining

Despite a relatively weak finish to 2015, the house building sector was
among the strongest performers last year. In this context, it being a
relative outperformer this year was always going to be a stern challenge.
In recent weeks, we have also seen the rejuvenation of a number of last
year’s laggards, including the Oil and Gas and Mining sectors. To cover
these positions, we believe investors have been engaging in a process of
sector rotation, and it seems entirely plausible that they should take
money out of the house building sector for this purpose.

Given these sectoral trends, it is worth noting a timely report published
yesterday by our European Equity Strategy team, Buying The Barbell, in
which our colleagues assert that Energy and Mining now “look expensive”.

11:42 am
BE

Skipping a bit to get to the London section.

BE

DPL klaxon.

BE

Fears of contagion from the high-end London segment downwards

We note an increase in short selling interest in recent weeks,
particularly in the case of Berkeley (short interest currently c6% of the
company’s free float), which has become the destination of choice for
those shorting prime London house prices. That Berkeley is much less
exposed to the prime London segment than it once was (witness large
schemes in Newham, Wapping and the Isle of Dogs) seems beside the point.

We have little doubt that market conditions are weaker at higher price
points, particularly in central London – this trend has been evident
throughout this year to date and during the whole of 2015 (in the early
months of last year, sentiment was weakened by fears of a Mansion Tax,
rent controls, etc). And we have little doubt that market conditions are
much stronger at entry level price points, a trend reinforced (in the new
build segment) by the introduction of Help to Buy London on 1st February
(Bellway reported that in the period since its introduction, 50% of its
reservations in London had been done through the scheme).

The London market is highly-cyclical and short sellers are well within
their rights to exploit this. That said, we believe that they should be
aware that Berkeley is demonstrably the highest returning house builder
in the sector (narrowly beating Persimmon along the way – see our note
Benchmarking The Builders) and, in principle, offers an annual dividend
yield of 6.7% in each of the next four years, based on our forecasts. Our
view is that any attempts to short the shares are predicated on this
scheme being unfulfilled, which is a significant proposition.

We also note fairly modest short positions elsewhere in the sector. Aside
from Berkeley (see above) and Redrow (c3% of free float) – which has some
financial leverage and London exposure – other house builders have short
positions of less than 1% of their free floats. In other words, the
weakness of the sector at large cannot be attributed to short sellers
alone.

11:43 am
BE

(DPL Klaxon would be a good name for an estate agent.)

BE

So, conclusions .....

BE

Conclusions

A number of factors continue to cast a pall over the UK house builders
and there is a very real possibility that this will remain the case in
the near term. We continue to believe that the fundamentals of house
building are strong – there exists an attractive, stable and disciplined
land buying market; sales are well underpinned by the Help to Buy scheme;
the economy is (for now at least) continuing to grow; rate rises seem to
be off the agenda. Where there are more challenging areas – notably prime
Central London – house builders’ exposure levels are quite modest. In
some cases (Persimmon and Bovis), it is possible to hold house builders
without any London exposure at all.

11:43 am
BE

As I say, that's from a few days ago but certainly reflects the consensus view.

11:51 am

PM

6 things I learnt in macro this week

PM

“Risk on” has to be the dominant theme this week.

11:52 am
PM

Certainly has to be when you employer has just decided to bin 20% of the local workforce

PM

or thereabouts

PM

Stocks are up, led by a 6.5% surge in
the Nikkei. Bonds have sold off in a good way with the US curve moderately flattening
and European peripheral bonds rallying. Oil has jumped over 10% and EM currencies
have outperformed. The only cloud has been the sell-off in Greek bonds – the 2yr is up
almost 2% in yield this past week (admittedly the market is very illiquid). Aside from
market price action, here are six things that stood out for me this week:

11:52 am
PM

You can have the rest in one hit

PM

1. US earnings have been great so far. It is early days in earnings season, but
upside surprises have dominated (helped by banks). The balance of positive to
negative surprises touched an all-time high this past week (see Figure 1).
2. China credit surged in Q1. The stabilisation in Chinese data has certainly
helped the recovery growth and risk. However, today’s data show credit picked
up sharply in recent months, so the foundation could be shaky (see Figure 2).
3. EM easing has started. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) surprised
yesterday by effectively easing through flattening the slope in its currency
range. With Brazil intervening heavily to offset currency strength, a broader
theme of greater intervention and easings in EM could be emerging.
4. Foreigners are dipping their toes back into Japanese stocks. International
investors fell out of love with Japanese stocks late last year, but the latest data
show the second week of net foreign buying of Japanese stocks (see Figure 3).
5. Inflation is picking up – at least in non-euro Europe. We had a raft of
inflation data this week. While the US disappointed, the UK, Sweden and
Norway all showed rising trends (see Figure 4).
6. Korea election surprise sets tone for 2016. Yesterday’s Korean general
election saw a divided opposition deliver a surprise victory over the ruling party.
It seems established parties cannot be assumed to deliver votes. This
weekend’s impeachment vote in Brazil is another example. Then there is the
UK Referendum on EU membership (23 June), Japanese elections (likely July)
and US elections (8 November).

undefined
11:54 am
PM

Don't fight on the right please

PM

PM

11:55 am

PM

Let me grab Cantor on what to expect from Doha.

11:58 am
BE

The upcoming meeting on April 17th in Doha has
received a lot of ink over the past week, but we still felt the need to chime in given the importance that
Sunday's news flow is likely to have on the crude market. We won't re-hash all the details, but will
instead cut to the bottom line: do we think the group will agree to a freeze this weekend? We have no
idea. It would be errant of us to claim we had insights into behind-the-scene discussions.
The more important question in our mind is, would a freeze matter? An agreement from the group
would, to some extent, mark a change in OPEC policy and a reaction to the decline in crude prices.
However, from a global crude supply perspective, we don't see an agreement to freeze production
at/near all-time highs as an improvement in fundamentals. Sure, it would prevent further gains in
production from any member agreeing to a freeze, but from our perspective most of OPEC and Russia
were already nearly pumping flat out (see Exhibit 1). And any freeze from the Doha group would not
likely include Iran and Brazil, two countries that have made clear their intentions to grow production
unfettered.
The second question we have is, if there is a freeze, will the members adhere to the decision? We cannot
predict the future, but recent history shows minimal willingness of OPEC nations to comply with broad,
cross-border agreements. So, even if there is an uptick in crude prices on the heels of headlines out
of Doha this weekend, only time will tell if the group actually limits production to stated levels. In
a rising tape, the temptation to cheat increases; each individual member could seize opportunities to
pump a few extra thousand barrels in an effort to mend dwindling reserve accounts.
The bottom line is, if we get a freeze agreement this weekend, we would expect a positive reaction
in the crude markets. However, from our perspective, any agreement would not change the nearterm
bearish fundamentals facing prices -- and these forces could ultimately regain control over crude
markets. Into year-end 2016, we think it will be the decline in U.S. production that begins to stabilize
the markets. U.S. supply has already begun to turn over, but any rapid rise in WTI could make the rally
self-defeating, in our view, if U.S. producers ramp activity and/or begin working through the drilled
but uncompleted (DUC) inventory.
While this weekend’s meeting is all about the supply side of the equation, we think it is important to
consider what 2016/2017 will bring for the demand side. Cantor's market strategist, Peter Cecchini, puts
forth an out of consensus view about demand and consumption based on an overall less constructive
strategy versus consensus on the health of the global economy into year-end 2016 and into 2017. We
are in agreement with this viewpoint, as slack demand could delay balancing forces and keep pressure
on crude prices.
